parameters: \pop[2]As soon as we enter the room, Klace makes sure to shut the door behind us.
\pop[2]A few moments later, he turns around to face me. He looks completely sober.
\pop[4]Sorry, I wasn't even really that drunk.
I just needed to get away from everything, you know?
\pop[2]I'm not sure I know, so I just shrug.
\pop[4]Don't you find it all a little suffocating, Delta?
I mean, this "fresh start" could just put you behind bars.
And my little hiatus, instead of inspiring me, could end my career.
\i[5]"I trust that we'll come out on top. There's no need to worry."
\i[0]"It's a little scary, but I know we'll face everything together."
\i[5]"I trust that we'll come out on top. There's no need to worry."
\pop[4]I wish you could spare a bit of your confidence.
Tonight was just one panic attack after another.
\c[23]Argus\c[0] could be waiting around every street corner.
\i[0]"It's a little scary, but I know we'll face everything together."
But it's not like we're fighting an easy battle.
\c[23]Argus\c[0] could be waiting for us around every street corner.
\pop[2]He takes out his phone, and unlocks it.
\pop[4]Did you know that \c[10]Cipher\c[0] isn't the first group to oppose \c[23]Argus\c[0]?
I've actually been looking into the history of all this.
You know, the fight to make \c[10]zeros\c[0] more equal?
\pop[2]\c[10]Cipher\c[0] isn't the first organization to try...?
\pop[2]Well, they've definitely gotten farther than any other group. That's for sure...
\pop[4]It seems that way, but there's just no way to confirm it.
Any information about the groups before \c[10]Cipher\c[0] is impossible to find.
I can only see that the heads of those groups were apprehended.
\pop[4]There's not a single mention of them after they were taken in.
But that's not normal. It's like a scrub job; and a thorough one, at that.
I recognize the pattern because I've seen it happen in the idol business.
\pop[4]I think we're climbing the wrong tree, Delta.
And every moment that passes, we get too high to jump back down.
It's more than I bargained for, and I just don't know what to do.
\i[1]"We should trust Isaac. He'd never put us in danger like that."
\i[1]"We should trust Isaac. He'd never put us in danger like that."
Or I mean, maybe he doesn't \c[14]know\c[0] about the danger.
We may be smaller scale than \c[10]Cipher\c[0], but we're rebelling all the same.
\pop[4]If this doesn't end in favor of the \c[10]zeros\c[0], we'll be in trouble.
I think Isaac is operating under the hope that \c[10]Cipher\c[0] will win.
But after looking into the history of these organizations? I'm skeptical.
\pop[4]It's very likely that \c[23]Argus\c[0] already knows who the leader of \c[10]Cipher\c[0] is.
And I bet they'll disappear without a trace, too. But \c[23]Argus\c[0] won't back down.
Any investigation, however small, has a chance of being traced back to us.
\i[1]"We shouldn't feel bad. We're fighting for what's right."
\i[1]"We shouldn't feel bad. We're fighting for what's right."
\pop[4]But it's against all odds, and that's what worries me.
Being a martyr is admirable and all; but not if the people forget you.
They could take us out, and then scrub our identities from existence.
\pop[4]In the backyard, they were all talking about "legacies" to leave behind.
But we're up against \c[23]Argus\c[0]. They can snap a finger, and we're just... gone.
No legacy. No martyrdom. We just messed with the wrong group, and paid for it.
\i[1]"There's no sign that we're in any danger. Not at all."
\i[1]"There's no sign that we're in any danger. Not at all."
\pop[4]Well, the anxiety of not knowing is really killing me.
I'm just... not sure if I'm supposed to be part of this group.
If we're all caught, then my career would be over, and I'd disappear!
\i[1]"I really don't think \c[23]Argus\c[0] is coming after us, Klace."
\i[1]"I really don't think \c[23]Argus\c[0] is coming after us, Klace."
\pop[4]You don't know how many times I've wanted to turn in Isaac...
How many times I've written the text, and had my finger over "send".
It's not easy, living like every day could be your last. It's terrifying.
\pop[4]But there's a reason I haven't done it yet.
There's a reason I've stuck by your side, and everyone else's.
I think my instinct to turn and run is just one the label forced on me.
\pop[4]Like I said, if we were caught, then my career would probably be over.
It says a lot, that I care more about my career than I do about myself.
They taught me to put that first, since it's the real moneymaker.
\pop[4]I'm always scared to do things, because of how they'd affect my image.
Even if they're things I want, and things I \c[14]know\c[0] would make me happy.
That's why I haven't turned in Isaac. It's what the label would want.
\pop[4]And I struggle with that every single day.
Especially since this hiatus has let me taste independence.
Whether we're caught, or I go back to work? I'll lose it either way...
\i[1]"Your career wouldn't end if we're caught."
\i[1]"Your career wouldn't end if we're caught."
There's not much love in the world for those who defy our leaders.
Especially for those who build a platform and use it for subterfuge.
\i[1]"Remember, public opinion is with the \c[10]zeros\c[0], not \c[23]Argus\c[0].
\i[1]"Remember, public opinion is with the \c[10]zeros\c[0], not \c[23]Argus\c[0].
\i[1]"If \c[10]Cipher\c[0] wins, you could be seen as a hero, or a pioneer."
\i[1]"If \c[10]Cipher\c[0] wins, you could be seen as a hero, or a pioneer."
\i[1]"Yeah. If \c[23]Argus\c[0] loses, then we won't be the bad guys."
\i[1]"Yeah. If \c[23]Argus\c[0] loses, then we won't be the bad guys."
\pop[4]I guess I just find it hard to believe that we'll come out on top.
But you're right. If the tables turn, we'll be on the other side.
I'm only just scared because they haven't moved yet.
\pop[4]Yeah, a revolution by giving out phones to all the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
They're giving \c[23]Argus\c[0] the chance to do it first, but I don't think they will.
I'd hate it \c[14]so\c[0] much if \c[10]zeros\c[0] dying of starvation was the catalyst for change.
\pop[4]Because then \c[14]how\c[0] do you decide how many lives are enough?
At what point would \c[10]Cipher\c[0] realize it's time to take action?
That both sides see any lives as expendable is just awful.
\pop[4]But it's the world we live in...
\pop[2]With a contrasting smirk, he gives me a playful nudge.
\pop[4]If this all goes our way, I definitely wouldn't mind being called a hero.
And it's good that we're close. Every hero needs a good sidekick, right?
\pop[2]I can tell that I've given him enough affirmation.
\pop[2]His doubt moves aside, and I'm met with optimism.
\pop[2]It's a trait that was definitely lacking before we started talking.
\pop[4]So, can I trust in you, then?
If I'm ever in trouble, you'll come to my rescue?
\i[1]"I figured it'd be the hero that rescues the sidekick, actually..."
\i[1]"I figured it'd be the hero that rescues the sidekick, actually..."
\pop[4]I guess it could go both ways.
Then we're more like a team...!
\pop[4]Every good team needs a name, though...
\pop[2]He's clearly having a hard time thinking of a name, so I decide to step up.
\pop[2]Given our interactions thus far, I have a pretty good idea for our team name.
\pop[2]He smiles, and gives my hand a firm shake.
\pop[4]Seems to describe a lot of us these days.
But I'm starting to see the light on the other side.
Maybe Isaac is right. Maybe we \c[14]will\c[0] be fine.
\pop[4]And even if we \c[14]aren't\c[0], at least I've got my sidekick.
Gotta say, always liked the idea of my own knight in shining armor.
Thanks for that chat, Delta. I knew you'd be the right choice.
\pop[4]But getting used to it more and more.
If I ever need someone to talk to again, I'll let you know.
That diary isn't exactly the best at giving me advice in return.
\pop[2]I nod and smile, sensing that the conversation has reached it's natural end.
\pop[2]With a quick good night, he jumps into bed. I take it as my cue to leave.
\pop[2]But on the way out of his room, something catches my attention.
\pop[2]His diary is resting on a desk that's placed against one of the walls.
\pop[2]Around it, are worrying amounts of empty booze, and pill bottles.
\pop[2]I immediately avert my gaze, as I feel like it's none of my business.
\pop[2]But then I immediately look back, a little shocked and worried.
\pop[2]It was clear that this was taking a toll on him, and I hated to see that.
\pop[2]But I can't start doubting him. I have to believe in him, and his words.
\pop[2]He'd never turn us in just to save himself...
\pop[2]At least, that's what I choose to tell myself as I leave him on his own.
\pop[2]In an effort to cleanse my mind, I check my phone as soon as I leave the room.
\pop[2]It looks like it's business as usual. I don't think anyone knows how Klace truly feels.
\pop[2]Right now, the main concern is that Dante left his wallet at The Wayfarer.
\pop[2]Now that I know more about him though, I offer to pick it up in the morning.
\pop[2]It was a keepsake, and it clearly had meaning to him, despite seeming otherwise.
\pop[2]He thanks me, and I return to my room.
\pop[2]Like last time, I plug in my phone and stare up at the ceiling.
\pop[2]But fatigue doesn't take me. It's replaced by a new wave of worry.
\pop[2]I worry about what might happen to my friends.
\pop[2]But I realize that we're all on the same team. We're in this together.
\pop[2]I cling to that feeling of togetherness, and hold it deep into a sleepless night...
